paragraphs.zh-tw: 我第一次進手術室觀摩實際手術時，沒預料會看到什麼。我當時是工科大學生。
paragraphs.en: The first time I stoodin the operating room and watched a real surgery, I had no idea what to expect. I was a college student in engineering.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我以為會像電視上演的一樣，播著緊張的背景音樂，豆大的汗珠由外科醫生臉上滑落。
paragraphs.en: I thought it was going to be like on TV. Ominous music playing in the background, beads of sweat pouring down the surgeon's face.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 但根本不是那樣。當天的確有播音樂，我想是瑪丹娜的金曲選輯。
paragraphs.en: But it wasn't like that at all. There was music playing on this day, I think it was Madonna's greatest hits.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 當時還有許多交談，話題除了病人心率外，還有運動跟週末計劃。我手術看得越多，就越懂那是怎麼回事。
paragraphs.en: And there was plenty of conversation, not just about the patient's heart rate, but about sports and weekend plans. And since then, the more surgeries I watched, the more I realized this is how it is.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 從某個古怪角度來看，這跟在辦公室沒兩樣。但有時，音樂聲會被轉小，所有人停止說話，眼睛盯著同樣的東西。
paragraphs.en: In some weird way, it's justanother day at the office. But every so often the music gets turned down, everyone stops talking, and stares at exactly the same thing.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 那時你就知道，有很重要、很危險的事情正在進行。首次遇到那狀況時，我正在觀摩腹腔鏡手術。為不熟悉的人說明一下，腹腔鏡手術不像傳統大切口的手術，腹腔鏡手術中，外科醫生在病人身上開三個以上的切口。
paragraphs.en: And that's when you knowthat something absolutely critical and dangerous is happening. The first time I saw that I was watching a type of surgery called laparoscopic surgery And for those of you who are unfamiliar, laparoscopic surgery, instead of the large open incision you mightbe used to with surgery, a laparoscopic surgeryis where the surgeon creates these three or more smallincisions in the patient.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 接著插入這些細長、附攝影機的器材，並透過它在病患體內進行手術。這很不錯，因為感染風險低、較少疼痛，恢復時間也更短。
paragraphs.en: And then inserts these long, thin instruments and a camera, and actually does the procedure inside the patient. This is great because there'smuch less risk of infection, much less pain, shorter recovery time.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 但這其中有著取捨，因為開這些切口用的是個尖長的器械，叫做穿刺套針。而外科醫生用這器械的方法是他抓著這東西，然後壓在你的腹部，直到它穿進去。
paragraphs.en: But there is a trade-off, because these incisions are created with a long, pointed device called a trocar. And the way the surgeon uses this device is that he takes it and he presses it into the abdomen until it punctures through.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 這就是為何在手術室的所有人在當時都盯著那東西看，因為他必須非常小心不要穿太過，以免刺穿下面的臟器和血管。但這問題大家都很熟，因為你們八成在其他地方看過了。
paragraphs.en: And now the reason why everyone in the operating room was staring at that device on that day was because he had to be absolutely careful not to plunge it through and puncture it into the organs and blood vessels below. But this problem should seem pretty familiar to all of you because I'm pretty sure you've seen it somewhere else.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 記得這個吧？你很清楚在某個時間點，吸管會刺穿，而你不知是否會穿透，戳到你的手，或把果汁噴得到處是。你怕死了。對吧？每次你做這件事，所體驗到的物理原理，都和我那天在手術室經歷的一樣。這顯然是個大問題。
paragraphs.en: Remember this? You knew that at any second that straw was going to plunge through, and you didn't know if it was going to go out the other side and straight into your hand, or if you were going toget juice everywhere, but you were terrified. Right? Every single time you did this, you experienced the samefundamental physics that I was watching in the operating room that day. And it turns out it really is a problem.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 2003 年，FDA 甚至出面表示：套針穿刺或許是在微創手術中最危險的步驟。2009 年，我們又看到一篇論文說：腹腔鏡手術的主要併發症有半數以上和穿刺套針有關。
paragraphs.en: In 2003, the FDA actually came out and said that trocar incisions might be the most dangerous step in minimally invasive surgery. Again in 2009, we see a paper that says that trocars account for over half of all major complications in laparoscopic surgery.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 噢！除此之外，這件事已經 25 年沒變了。所以我上研究所時，就想做這東西。
paragraphs.en: And, oh by the way, this hasn't changed for 25 years. So when I got to graduate school, this is what I wanted to work on.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我試著跟朋友解釋我到底在忙什麼，我說：「這就像你為了掛東西鑽牆壁那樣。鑽子在鑽穿牆壁那個瞬間會爆衝一下。對吧？」然後他看著我說：「你是說，像他們鑽人腦袋那樣？」然後我說：「啥？！」我後來查了一下，發現他們真會這麼做。
paragraphs.en: I was trying to explain to a friend of mine what exactly I was spending my time doing, and I said, "It's like when you're drilling through a wall to hang something in your apartment. There's that moment when the drillfirst punctures through the wall and there's this plunge. Right? And he looked at me and he said, "You mean like when they drill into people's brains?" And I said, "Excuse me?" And then I looked it up and theydo drill into people's brains.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 很多的神經外科手術第一步就是在你顱骨上鑽個洞。如果外科醫生不謹慎，他有可能會直接戳到腦部。
paragraphs.en: A lot of neurosurgical procedures actually start with a drillincision through the skull. And if the surgeon isn't careful, he can plunge directly into the brain.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 從那時候我開始思考，好，顱骨鑽孔、腹腔鏡手術，那其他醫學領域呢？你想想，哪次你去看醫生沒被塞點什麼，是吧？事實就是，在醫學上，穿刺無所不在。而這只是我查到的幾種手術，其中有組織穿刺的步驟。
paragraphs.en: So this is the moment when I started thinking, okay, cranial drilling, laparoscopic surgery, why not other areas of medicine? Because think about it, when wasthe last time you went to the doctor and you didn't get stuck with something? Right? So the truth is in medicine puncture is everywhere. And here are just a coupleof the procedures that I've found that involve some tissue puncture step.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 如果我們只看其中三種──腹腔鏡手術、硬膜外麻醉、顱骨鑽孔──而這些手術引發了超過三萬起的併發症，而這只是這個國家一年的數字。我認為這是個值得解決的問題。
paragraphs.en: And if we take just three of them — laparoscopic surgery, epidurals, and cranial drilling — these procedures account for over 30,000 complications every year in this country alone. I call that a problem worth solving.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 讓我們來看一些用在這類手術的器械。我提過硬膜外麻醉。這是硬膜外套針。
paragraphs.en: So let's take a look at some of the devices that are used in these types of procedures. I mentioned epidurals. This is an epidural needle.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 他用來穿刺脊椎韌帶，在分娩時注射麻醉藥。這是組骨髓切片取樣工具，
paragraphs.en: It's used to puncture through the ligaments in the spine and deliver anesthesia during childbirth. Here's a set of bone marrow biopsy tools.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 用來做骨骼穿孔，並收集骨髓，或做骨骼病變的取樣。這是南北戰爭的刺刀。
paragraphs.en: These are actually usedto burrow into the bone and collect bone marrowor sample bone lesions. Here's a bayonette from the Civil War.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 若我告訴你這是醫學穿刺器材，你說不定真會相信我。因為這沒什麼不同嘛！我越深入研究，越是覺得一定有更好的做法。
paragraphs.en: If I had told you it was a medical puncture device you probably would have believed me. Because what's the difference? So, the more I did this research the more I thought there has to be a better way to do this.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 對我來說，問題的關鍵在於所有的這些穿刺器材都遵循同一套物理原理。什麼原理呢？讓我們回到鑽牆壁。
paragraphs.en: And for me the key to this problem is that all these different puncture devices share a common set of fundamental physics. So what are those physics? Let's go back to drilling through a wall.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 你透過鑽子對牆施加壓力，牛頓告訴我們，牆壁會給我們反作用力，等量且反向。
paragraphs.en: So you're applying a force on a drill towards the wall. And Newton says the wallis going to apply force back, equal and opposite.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 當你正在鑽的時候，兩力平衡。但在某個瞬間，牆壁會被鑽穿，牆壁將無法再提供反作用力。
paragraphs.en: So, as you drill through the wall, those forces balance. But then there's that moment when the drill first puncturesthrough the other side of the wall, and right at that moment the wall can't push back anymore.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 但你的大腦還來不及對變化作出反應，有幾毫秒時間──依你的反應速度而定，你還在施加壓力。而不平衡的力造成加速度，導致爆衝。
paragraphs.en: But your brain hasn't reacted to that change in force. So for that millisecond, or however long it takes you to react, you're still pushing, and that unbalanced force causes an acceleration, and that is the plunge.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 但如果在刺穿瞬間，你能夠將針尖往加速的反方向縮回呢？那就是我要做的。想像你有種器材，它有用來刺穿組織的針尖。
paragraphs.en: But what if right at the moment of puncture you could pull that tip back, actually oppose the forward acceleration? That's what I set out to do. So imagine you have a device and it's got some kind of sharp tip to cut through tissue.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 把針尖縮回的最簡單方法是什麼？我選擇了彈簧。當彈簧拉伸，針尖便伸出，就能穿刺組織。彈簧會想拉回針尖。
paragraphs.en: What's the simplest way you could pull that tip back? I chose a spring. So when you extend that spring, you extend that tip out so it's ready to puncture tissue, the spring wants to pull the tip back.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 你如何在穿透前，固定住針尖呢？我採用這機械結構。當針尖受到組織的反作用力，這機構會向外撐向內壁。
paragraphs.en: How do you keep the tip in place until the moment of puncture? I used this mechanism. When the tip of the deviceis pressed against tissue, the mechanism expands outwards and wedges in place against the wall.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 而其產生的摩擦力會鎖定針尖，阻止彈簧將它縮回。但在穿透瞬間，組織不再提供反作用力。
paragraphs.en: And the friction that's generated locks it in place and preventsthe spring from retracting the tip. But right at the moment of puncture, the tissue can't push backon the tip anymore.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 所以機構解鎖，彈簧將針尖縮回。看一下慢動作。
paragraphs.en: So the mechanism unlocks and the spring retracts the tip. Let me show you that happening in slow motion.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 這大約每秒 2,000 畫格。注意針尖的部分，在畫面下方，即將刺穿組織。你會發現在刺穿的瞬間，在這，機構解鎖，針尖縮回。
paragraphs.en: This is about 2,000 frames a second, and I'd like you to notice the tip that's right there on the bottom, about to puncture through tissue. And you'll see that right at the moment of puncture, right there, the mechanism unlocks and retracts that tip back.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我們拉近點再看一次。你會看到那尖銳的針尖，在它刺穿橡膠膜的瞬間，會縮進那個鈍邊白色套管。
paragraphs.en: I want to show it to you again, a little closer up. You're going to see the sharp bladed tip, and right when it punctures that rubber membrane it's going to disappearinto this white blunt sheath.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 在這。這一切都在百分之四秒內發生。
paragraphs.en: Right there. That happens within four 100ths of a second after puncture.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 而且因為這項設計是遵循穿刺的物理原理而非針對顱骨鑽孔、腹腔鏡手術或其他手術，其適用範圍涵蓋醫學各領域，以及各種不同規模。但它不見得長這樣。
paragraphs.en: And because this device is designedto address the physics of puncture and not the specifics of cranial drilling or laparoscopic surgery, or another procedure, it's applicable across thesedifferent medical disciplines and across different length scales. But it didn't always look like this.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 這是我作品的原型。對，那是冰棒棍，頂部那是橡皮筋。
paragraphs.en: This was my first prototype. Yes, those are popsicle sticks, and there's a rubber band at the top.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 做這只花 30 分鐘，但成品就有用了。它證明我的想法可行，並讓我接下來幾年的付出有所憑據。
paragraphs.en: It took about 30 minutes to do this, but it worked. And it proved to me that my idea worked and it justified the next coupleyears of work on this project.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我投入其中，因為這問題讓我著迷，甚至使我夜不能眠。
paragraphs.en: I worked on this because this problem really fascinated me. It kept me up at night.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 但我想這也該吸引你，因為穿刺無所不在。意味著在某個時刻，那也將成為你的問題。
paragraphs.en: But I think it should fascinate you too, because I said puncture is everywhere. That means at some point it's going to be your problem too.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 進手術室第一天，我沒料到有天穿刺套針會用在我身上。但去年，我在希臘時患上闌尾炎。
paragraphs.en: That first day in the operating room I never expected to find myself on the other end of a trocar. But last year, I got appendicitis when I was visiting Greece.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我在雅典的醫院，外科醫生告知我他將進行腹腔鏡手術。他將透過那些小切口切除闌尾，接著他告訴我預期的康復狀況、接下來會做什麼。
paragraphs.en: So I was in the hospital in Athens, and the surgeon was telling me he was going to perform a laparoscopic surgery. He was going to remove my appendix through these tiny incisions, and he was talking about whatI could expect for the recovery, and what was going to happen.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 他說：「你有什麼問題嗎？」我說：「只有一個。你們用的是哪種穿刺套針？」關於腹腔鏡手術，我最愛的引語出自雅各貝烏斯醫師：「造成風險的，是穿刺本身。」這是我最愛的引語，因為雅各貝烏斯是在人體進行腹腔鏡手術的第一人。而他在 1912 年寫下這句話。
paragraphs.en: He said, "Do you have any questions?"And I said, "Just one, doc. What kind of trocar do you use?" So my favorite quote about laparoscopic surgery comes from a Doctor H. C. Jacobaeus: "It is puncture itself that causes risk." That's my favorite quote because H.C. Jacobaeus was the first person to ever perform laparoscopic surgery on humans, and he wrote that in 1912.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 這問題傷害人們，甚至致人於死已超過百年之久。你可以安逸地想說，重要問題已有一群專家不眠不休致力解決。
paragraphs.en: This is a problem that's been injuring andeven killing people for over 100 years. So it's easy to think that forevery major problem out there there's some team of experts working around the clock to solve it.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 真相是，事情並非總如此。我們得找到這樣的問題，並找方法解決。
paragraphs.en: The truth is that's not always the case. We have to be better at finding those problems and finding ways to solve them.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 所以若你遇到那種「刺眼」的問題，讓自己夜以繼日地投入吧！讓自己為其著迷，因為有太多的生命，正待幫助。
paragraphs.en: So if you come across a problem that grabs you, let it keep you up at night. Allow yourself to be fascinated, because there are so many lives to save.

title: Nikolai Begg A Tool To Fix One Of The Most Dangerous Moments In Surgery
